items.title: SA Labor stalwart and former federal minister Nick Bolkus dies
items.description: Nick Bolkus, the long-time Labor senator who played an influential role in shaping Australia's migration policy under prime minister Paul Keating, has died aged 75.

items.title: 14 nations condemn Israel's 19 new West Bank settlements
items.description:
Fourteen countries issued a joint statement on Wednesday condemning Israel's recent approval of 19 new settlements in the occupied West Bank, warning the decision violates international law and threatens regional stability. Notably absent from the condemnation was the United States, making it the only G7 nation not to sign the statement[1][2][3].

The coalition—comprising Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Iceland, Ireland, Japan, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, and the United Kingdom—called on Israel to reverse the decision and halt all settlement expansion in line with UN Security Council Resolution 2334[1][4][5].

items.title: PM, Jewish leaders condemn apparent firebombing of Hanukkah car
items.description: Authorities were called to a St Kilda East residence about 3am, where a car with a sign celebrating the Jewish holiday had been set alight.

items.title: Pope Leo criticises 'distorted economy' in first Christmas mass
items.description: Pope Leo XIV holds the first Christmas mass of his pontificate, greeting thousands of faithful in St Peter's Square before the Christmas Eve service.

items.title: North Korea tests anti-aircraft missiles as US sub docks in South

featured_image.name: North Korea's Kim Jong Un Oversees Test of New Anti-Air ...

items.description:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un oversaw the test-firing of new high-altitude, long-range anti-aircraft missiles on Wednesday, with the weapons accurately hitting mock targets at an altitude of 200 kilometers in the East Sea, state media reported Thursday[1][2][3][4][5][6][7].

The test came one day after the USS Greeneville, a U.S. Navy nuclear-powered submarine, arrived at the South Korean port of Busan for crew rest and resupply[8][9][10]. In response, North Korea's Defense Ministry vowed to consider "countermeasures corresponding to the U.S. nuclear muscle flexing," calling the submarine's presence "a grave act of destabilization that escalates military tensions on the Korean Peninsula"[1][11][12].

items.title: White Christmas in Tasmania as heat climbs in other states
items.description: Snow has arrived in Tasmania on Christmas morning, but hotter conditions are expected around the country, including a scorcher in the west. The Bureau of Meteorology said rain was turning into snow before it hit the ground above 700 metres. Meanwhile, Western Australia has been in the grip of a heatwave, with the temperature in Perth expected to soar above 40C on Christmas Day.

items.title: Trump-backed Asfura wins disputed Honduras election

featured_image.name: Trump-Backed Honduras Candidate Asfura Wins Presidential ...

items.description:
Conservative candidate Nasry Asfura has won Honduras' presidential election after more than three weeks of vote counting marred by technical failures, fraud allegations and accusations of U.S. interference, the National Electoral Council announced Wednesday.

Asfura, a 67-year-old businessman and former mayor of Tegucigalpa backed by President Donald Trump, secured 40.3% of the votes, narrowly defeating center-right Liberal Party candidate Salvador Nasralla, who received 39.5%[1][2]. The results from the November 30 election required a manual recount of approximately 15% of ballot tally sheets—representing hundreds of thousands of votes—due to inconsistencies in the disorganized counting system[1][2].

items.title: Nvidia licenses Groq AI tech, dispels $20B buyout report

featured_image.name: AI chip startup Groq discusses $6 billion valuation, The ...

items.description:
Nvidia and AI chip startup Groq moved swiftly to dispel reports of a $20 billion acquisition on Wednesday, announcing instead a non-exclusive licensing agreement for Groq's inference technology[1][2][3].

The clarification came hours after CNBC reported that Nvidia had agreed to purchase Groq for $20 billion in cash, citing Alex Davis, CEO of investment firm Disruptive, which led Groq's most recent funding round[4][5][6]. The reported deal would have marked Nvidia's largest acquisition ever, surpassing its $7 billion purchase of Israeli chip designer Mellanox in 2019[4][6].

However, both companies confirmed the arrangement is a technology licensing agreement, not an acquisition. "Groq will continue to operate as an independent company," Groq announced on its website[3][7]. Under the agreement, Groq founder Jonathan Ross, President Sunny Madra, and other team members will join Nvidia to help advance the licensed technology, while Simon Edwards steps into the role of CEO at Groq[3][7].

items.title: Christmas Day cyclone greets remote Australian islands
items.description: Tropical Cyclone Grant is expected to remain a category one system as it passes just to the north of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands off the West Australian coast.

items.title: White House official says US forces to focus on 'quarantine' of Venezuela
items.description: The White House has ordered US military forces to focus almost exclusively on enforcing the "quarantine" of Venezuelan oil, a US official says.

items.title: Iran's Khamenei authorized compact nuclear warheads, report claims

featured_image.name: Has Iran's Khamenei authorised small nuclear weapons? What we ...

items.description:
Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei authorized the development of compact nuclear warheads for ballistic missiles in October, marking a reversal of years of restraint following the June war with Israel, according to a report released Wednesday by the Italian Institute for International Political Studies[1][2][3].

The authorization does not permit uranium enrichment beyond 60 percent, ISPI reported, citing sources in Tehran who had previously denied any such decision existed[2][3]. The Italian think tank indicated that Khamenei had consistently blocked the final decision to escalate to 90 percent weapons-grade enrichment and initiate miniaturized warhead creation, despite pressure from the Revolutionary Guards[2][3].

ISPI's analysis suggests the June conflict fundamentally altered Iran's strategic calculus. The 12-day war, which ran from June 13-24, revealed Iran's air defense systems were largely ineffective, with only medium-range missile capabilities proving reliable[2][3][4]. Tehran may have concluded that nuclear weapons would serve as its only viable deterrent against Israel and the United States, the report stated[2][3].

items.title: A million more Epstein files found, US government says
items.description: The Department of Justice says the release of the Epstein files will take "a few more weeks" after a million additional documents were uncovered.

items.title: China shatters launch record with 89 orbital missions

featured_image.name: China launches 1st set of spacecraft for planned 13,000 ...

items.description:
China has shattered its annual orbital launch record in 2025, conducting more than 80 missions by late December and maintaining an uninterrupted human presence aboard its Tiangong space station for over three years, while also launching its first asteroid exploration mission in a year marked by significant space achievements[1][2][3][4].

The country pushed its orbital launch total to at least 89 attempts by late December, far exceeding the previous record of 68 missions set in 2024[2][3][1]. In early December, China demonstrated its accelerating space capabilities by launching three Long March rockets within 19 hours, setting a new national record for launch cadence and bringing the year's total to 83 at that time[4][5][6][7].

items.title: 'Aussie' poster in Adelaide vandalised with 'white power' graffiti
items.description: An Adelaide street artist's poster aimed at provoking thought about national identity has been vandalised with racist graffiti.

items.title: These men fled Ukraine, but found Europe far less welcoming
items.description: Since Russia launched its full-scale invasion in 2022 thousands of men have fled Ukraine. Once welcomed, they are increasingly finding a Europe that is running out of patience.

items.title: Newly unsealed Epstein emails raise questions about Prince Andrew

featured_image.name: New Epstein files bring up former Prince Andrew connections ...

items.description:
The U.S. Justice Department released nearly 30,000 pages of Jeffrey Epstein-related documents Tuesday, including 2001 emails between Ghislaine Maxwell and an individual signing as "A" from Balmoral who requested "new inappropriate friends," with multiple pieces of evidence pointing to Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor[1][2][3][4][5].

The August 16, 2001 email from someone using the pseudonym "The Invisible Man" began: "I am up here at Balmoral Summer Camp for the Royal Family," before asking Maxwell, "Have you found me some new inappropriate friends?"[4][5] Maxwell responded the same day expressing disappointment that she could "only find appropriate friends"[4][6].

items.title: China hits record 89 space launches in 2025

featured_image.name: LandSpace Successfully Debuts Zhuque-3, Falls Barely Short of ...

items.description:
China capped a banner year in space with 89 orbital launches through December 23, shattering its previous annual record and marking significant advances in reusable rocket technology and deep-space exploration[1][2][3].

The nation's latest milestone came Monday when its Long March 12A reusable rocket successfully reached orbit but failed to recover its first stage during a landing attempt at Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center[2][3]. The test followed a similar December 3 attempt by commercial firm LandSpace, whose Zhuque-3 rocket reached orbit but crashed during its landing burn[4][5][6].

China's 2025 launch total far exceeded the 68 missions flown in 2024[4][7][8]. According to the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission, the country placed 322 satellites in orbit through November 30, a 22 percent increase over the previous year[4]. The surge was driven largely by deployments for two megaconstellations—the government-backed Guowang and Shanghai's Qianfan—each designed to exceed 10,000 satellites to compete with SpaceX's Starlink network[9][10][11].

items.title: Intel shares fall after Nvidia halts chip testing

featured_image.name: Inside Intel’s new Arizona fab, where the chipmaker’s fate hangs in the balance

items.description:
Intel shares fell Wednesday morning after reports emerged that Nvidia discontinued testing of the chipmaker's advanced 18A manufacturing process, dealing a blow to Intel's efforts to compete as a contract manufacturer.

The stock dropped approximately 2.3% to 2.7% in premarket trading on December 24, according to multiple outlets[1][2][3]. Reuters first reported that Nvidia recently tested Intel's so-called 18A process but stopped moving forward, citing two unidentified sources familiar with the matter[4][5][6]. Broadcom also conducted similar testing, the report said[2][7].

An Intel spokesperson told Reuters the company's 18A manufacturing technologies are "progressing well" and that it "continues to see strong interest" for its next-generation production process[6][8]. Neither Nvidia nor Broadcom representatives responded to requests for comment from Reuters[9][5].

items.title: Space agencies plan historic moon, Mars missions in 2026

featured_image.name: 6 spaceflights ahead in 2026, from NASA moon missions to SpaceX Starship

items.description:
International space agencies are gearing up for an intensive year of lunar and interplanetary exploration, with NASA, China, India, and Europe planning historic missions that could reshape human understanding of the solar system.

NASA's Artemis II mission leads the charge, targeting a launch as early as February 5, 2026, according to agency officials[1][2]. The 10-day lunar flyby will carry four astronauts—Commander Reid Wiseman, pilot Victor Glover, mission specialist Christina Koch, and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen—marking humanity's first crewed journey beyond low Earth orbit since Apollo 17 in 1972[3][4]. The crew has named their Orion spacecraft "Integrity"[5][6].

China plans to launch Chang'e 7 to the Moon's south pole in August 2026, where the mission will search for water ice deposits using an innovative "hopping" probe equipped with a water molecule analyzer[7][8]. The spacecraft will include an orbiter, lander, rover, and flying probe, spending up to two months examining permanently shadowed craters near Shackleton crater[7][9]. China also expects to launch its Xuntian space telescope by late December 2026, a facility with a field of view 300 times larger than Hubble's that will co-orbit with the Tiangong space station[10][11].

India's space agency ISRO aims to conduct its first uncrewed Gaganyaan test flight by March 2026, carrying Vyommitra, a humanoid test robot[12][13]. The mission will validate critical systems for India's planned 2027 crewed spaceflight, making India potentially the fourth nation to independently launch astronauts[12][14]. ISRO Chairman V. Narayanan confirmed that 90% of Gaganyaan's development work has been completed, with human-rated launch vehicles and life support systems nearing completion[15].

items.title: US and Ukraine reach consensus on key issues to end war with Russia
items.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said that Ukraine has reached consensus with the US on key issues to end the war with Russia but sensitive issues around territorial control, along with the management of a nuclear power plant, still remain unresolved.

items.title: Russia says talks on US peace plan for Ukraine 'are proceeding constructively'
items.description: A Kremlin envoy says peace talks on a U.S.-proposed plan to end the nearly four-year war in Ukraine are proceeding constructively in Florida[2].

items.title: Indonesian court sentences an Australian to 12 years in prison for smuggling cocaine to Bali
items.description: Indonesian court sentences an Australian to 12 years in prison for smuggling cocaine to Bali[2].

items.title: At least 9 killed, 10 wounded in South African pub shooting
items.description: Authorities report that nine people have died and at least 10 others are injured after a shooting at a South African pub[2].

items.title: Saudi Arabia quietly expands access to its only alcohol store for non-Muslim residents
items.description: Saudi Arabia has quietly expanded access to its only alcohol store, now allowing non-Muslim Premium Residency holders to purchase alcohol legally[2].

items.title: Iraq's political future in limbo as factions vie for power
items.description: Political factions in Iraq have been maneuvering since the parliamentary election more than a month ago to form alliances that will shape the next government[2].

items.title: Australia marks Day of Reflection for Bondi Beach shooting victims
items.description: Australians are lighting candles Sunday to remember the victims of a mass shooting at a Jewish festival in Sydney's Bondi Beach[2].

items.title: US Coast Guard seizes second sanctioned vessel in the Caribbean, officials say
items.description: The U.S. Coast Guard has interdicted a second sanctioned vessel off the coast of Venezuela in international waters of the Caribbean Sea[2].

items.title: Egypt's el-Sissi urges UN Security Council reforms for Africa's larger role
items.description: Egypt’s President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi has called for changes in the U.N. Security Council to give Africa a bigger role in global decisions[2].

items.title: Australian state plans tougher laws against displaying extremist flags after Bondi shooting
items.description: The Australian state of New South Wales is proposing a ban on public displays of Islamic State group flags and extremist symbols[2].

items.title: Pakistani court sentences former PM Imran Khan and wife to 17 years in graft case
items.description: A Pakistani court has convicted former Prime Minister Imran Khan and his wife, Bushra Bibi, sentencing them to 17 years in prison[2].
